awd_titl_txt: Glycosyl Sulfonates for the Construction of Difficult Glycosidic Linkages
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the NSF Chemistry Division is supporting the research of Professor Clay Bennett of Tufts University who is developing ways to make sugar molecules attach to each other at specific locations without forming mixtures of products. Being able to control the attachment of sugar molecules is important because it influences the reactivity of these compounds in different systems. Chains of sugar molecules are called oligosaccharides and are found on the surfaces of cells, are structural components of plants, and often control biological processes. Professor Bennett and his research group will determine which components of sugar molecules match best with a reagent to help form the desired connections. They will then test what they learn from these studies by making a known antibiotic compound. Determining how to make sugar molecules link together at specific locations will increase efficiency in oligosaccharide synthesis and decrease waste associated with separating mixtures of products. The results of this research impact all areas of activity that require carbohydrate synthesis, including agricultural, chemical, and pharmaceutical industries. This project also involves outreach activities to high school chemistry students to introduce the chemistry of sugar molecules.

The Bennett lab is using sulfonyl chloride promoters to control the stereochemical outcome of glycosylation reactions of deoxysugars. These reactions are difficult to control due to the lack of a directing group so finding ways to achieve this selectivity is important. Three specific areas of investigation are being pursued: 1) monitoring the reactivity of different deoxy sugars and sulfonyl chlorides to create a database cataloging which promoter is best for which sugar, 2) determining the chemical interactions that control these transformations, and 3) demonstrating the utility of the method with the synthesis of saccharomicin B. Lessons learned from these studies may allow for the synthesis of challenging oligosaccharides without the need for wasteful separation procedures. This program will provide an excellent training environment for a diverse group of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes

Research Outcomes.

Oligosaccharides, or complex carbohydrates, are biopolymers which are found throughout all kingdoms of life.  These molecules paly a variety of roles including, but not limited to promoting cell adhesion, aiding in the immune response, and controlling the biological activity of many natural products.  Given the diversity of roles these molecules play, they hold enormous potential to serve as next-generation therapeutics.  A major hurdle to the further advancement of these molecules lies in the challenges in obtaining pure material.  Unlike other biopolymers, like nucleic acids and proteins, oligosaccharides are often produced as complex mixtures, which can be difficult or impossible to separate.  This leaves chemical synthesis as the only avenue for the large-scale production of homogeneous oligosaccharides.  The synthesis of these molecules is far from trivial, however, and with existing technologies the synthesis of a single oligosaccharide can take months or even years to accomplish.  One of the major challenges in oligosaccharide synthesis lies in controlling the stereochemical outcome of the glycosylation reactions used to assemble monosaccharides into larger oligosaccharides.  In a typical glycosylation reaction, it is possible to produce two different isomers, termed a- and b-anomers.  Because the two different anomers often possess very different biological activities, it is desirable to only produce products as a single isomer.  While this is possible for certain classes of oligosaccharides, many of these compounds are possess linkages between monosaccharides which are extremely challenging to synthesize.  This is especially the case for a class of molecules called deoxy-sugars, which are important components of bioactive natural products.  The research supported by this grant allowed us to develop new methods for the highly selective synthesis of deoxy-sugar oligosaccharides.  Furthermore, this work has allowed us to demonstrate the utility of this chemistry through the construction of several deoxy-sugar oligosaccharides.

Through these studies we developed new glycosylation chemistries for the stereoselective construction of b-linked 2-deoxy-sugars, which are generally considered to be one of the most difficult glycosidic linkages to synthesize in a reliable fashion.  This is achieved by activating a deoxy-sugar hemiacetal with a sulfonyl chloride promoter system.  Importantly, we have found that optimal selectivity in these reactions is obtained by matching the reactivity of the deoxy-sugar hemiacetal with the sulfonyl chloride promoter.  This observation is leading us to build predictive models for deoxy-sugar oligosaccharide synthesis to make the process routine.  In addition, we have found that through proper selection of sulfonyl chloride reagent it is possible to reverse the selectivity of the reaction.  Finally, we have also developed chemistries for the construction of carbohydrate analogs where the molecules are linked through carbon atoms, thus rendering them more stable.

More importantly, we have also demonstrated that this chemistry can be used for the synthesis of complex deoxy-sugar oligosaccharides.  This was demonstrated through the construction of three highly congested oligosaccharides.  In the case of one of these molecules we have developed a significantly improved synthesis over previously reported routes.  In the case of the other two, this work represents the first time these molecules have ever been synthesized.   This chemistry will greatly facilitate oligosaccharide synthesis, and has already been adopted by other synthetic chemists to solve difficult problems in oligosaccharide construction.  Thus, this research has laid the foundations for the rapid and routine construction of oligosaccharides.

In addition to its impact on organic synthesis and carbohydrate chemistry, the work funded under this grant has also helped train future scientists at several educational levels.  During this grant the PI mentored six graduate students, four of whom have obtained a Ph.D.  In addition, this research provided five undergraduate students with the opportunity to carry out research.  The impact on the undergraduate students' education is evidenced by the fact that many of these students have gone on to top Ph.D. programs and medical schools.  Finally, a portion of the funds in this award has been used to carry out outreach programs with Tufts University's local host community of Somerville, MA, where we have worked with the Somerville High School (SHS) chemistry students.  Specifically, we have set up a workshop in which SHS students travel to the Tufts University Department of Chemistry to carry out and analyze chemical reactions.  The goal of this program is to give students a more hands-on experience with chemistry in order to stimulate their desire to enter STEM fields.  Importantly, since our host community is diverse, many students from groups who are historically underrepresented in the sciences have taken part in these outreach activities.


Last Modified: 09/19/2023
Modified by: Clay Bennett

Project Outcomes

Research Outcomes.

Oligosaccharides, or complex carbohydrates, are biopolymers which are found throughout all kingdoms of life.  These molecules paly a variety of roles including, but not limited to promoting cell adhesion, aiding in the immune response, and controlling the biological activity of many natural products.  Given the diversity of roles these molecules play, they hold enormous potential to serve as next-generation therapeutics.  A major hurdle to the further advancement of these molecules lies in the challenges in obtaining pure material.  Unlike other biopolymers, like nucleic acids and proteins, oligosaccharides are often produced as complex mixtures, which can be difficult or impossible to separate.  This leaves chemical synthesis as the only avenue for the large-scale production of homogeneous oligosaccharides.  The synthesis of these molecules is far from trivial, however, and with existing technologies the synthesis of a single oligosaccharide can take months or even years to accomplish.  One of the major challenges in oligosaccharide synthesis lies in controlling the stereochemical outcome of the glycosylation reactions used to assemble monosaccharides into larger oligosaccharides.  In a typical glycosylation reaction, it is possible to produce two different isomers, termed a- and b-anomers.  Because the two different anomers often possess very different biological activities, it is desirable to only produce products as a single isomer.  While this is possible for certain classes of oligosaccharides, many of these compounds are possess linkages between monosaccharides which are extremely challenging to synthesize.  This is especially the case for a class of molecules called deoxy-sugars, which are important components of bioactive natural products.  The research supported by this grant allowed us to develop new methods for the highly selective synthesis of deoxy-sugar oligosaccharides.  Furthermore, this work has allowed us to demonstrate the utility of this chemistry through the construction of several deoxy-sugar oligosaccharides.

Through these studies we developed new glycosylation chemistries for the stereoselective construction of b-linked 2-deoxy-sugars, which are generally considered to be one of the most difficult glycosidic linkages to synthesize in a reliable fashion.  This is achieved by activating a deoxy-sugar hemiacetal with a sulfonyl chloride promoter system.  Importantly, we have found that optimal selectivity in these reactions is obtained by matching the reactivity of the deoxy-sugar hemiacetal with the sulfonyl chloride promoter.  This observation is leading us to build predictive models for deoxy-sugar oligosaccharide synthesis to make the process routine.  In addition, we have found that through proper selection of sulfonyl chloride reagent it is possible to reverse the selectivity of the reaction.  Finally, we have also developed chemistries for the construction of carbohydrate analogs where the molecules are linked through carbon atoms, thus rendering them more stable.

More importantly, we have also demonstrated that this chemistry can be used for the synthesis of complex deoxy-sugar oligosaccharides.  This was demonstrated through the construction of three highly congested oligosaccharides.  In the case of one of these molecules we have developed a significantly improved synthesis over previously reported routes.  In the case of the other two, this work represents the first time these molecules have ever been synthesized.   This chemistry will greatly facilitate oligosaccharide synthesis, and has already been adopted by other synthetic chemists to solve difficult problems in oligosaccharide construction.  Thus, this research has laid the foundations for the rapid and routine construction of oligosaccharides.

In addition to its impact on organic synthesis and carbohydrate chemistry, the work funded under this grant has also helped train future scientists at several educational levels.  During this grant the PI mentored six graduate students, four of whom have obtained a Ph.D.  In addition, this research provided five undergraduate students with the opportunity to carry out research.  The impact on the undergraduate students' education is evidenced by the fact that many of these students have gone on to top Ph.D. programs and medical schools.  Finally, a portion of the funds in this award has been used to carry out outreach programs with Tufts University's local host community of Somerville, MA, where we have worked with the Somerville High School (SHS) chemistry students.  Specifically, we have set up a workshop in which SHS students travel to the Tufts University Department of Chemistry to carry out and analyze chemical reactions.  The goal of this program is to give students a more hands-on experience with chemistry in order to stimulate their desire to enter STEM fields.  Importantly, since our host community is diverse, many students from groups who are historically underrepresented in the sciences have taken part in these outreach activities.
